   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for ascites and
   bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management of
   hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   .
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).
   - MAPs > 60
   - SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 50 mg IV x 1 upon arrival to floor
   - vanc/zosyn; consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - would consider pulling R subclav
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Also intubated [**Date range (1) 3633**] on
   surgery for hypotension.
   - placed on pressure control because of high PIPs on AC
   - vanc/zosyn as above
   - will place a-line for ABGs
   - will consider therapeutic para to reduce intra-abdominal pressures
   and improve respiratory mechanics
   .
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   .
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if BPs stable
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   .
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - HD likely today
   - renal reccs
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / regular diet
   # PPX: PPI, heparin SQ, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: PIV

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD. He was admitted for upper extremity gangrene and underwent a left brachial to radial bypass, which was complicated by a perioperative MI. He developed bradycardia, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia, requiring intubation and pressors. He also has ascites, which was tapped on 1/13 and negative for SBP, but cytology was not sent. An RUQ US showed evidence of cirrhosis and a hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC. He has been followed by multiple services including vascular surgery, plastic surgery, cardiology, nephrology, and hepatology.

24-Hour Events:
- The patient's oxygen requirement increased, and SBPs dropped from the 100s to the 80s.
- He underwent a diagnostic para after receiving albumin 50g and was started on ceftriaxone.
- Blood cultures were drawn at 9:10 PM on 1/23 and 6:00 AM on 1/24.
- Sputum and stool cultures were also obtained.
- The patient developed a fever of 102.4 at 5:00 AM on 1/24.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD, who has been admitted multiple times for various conditions. He is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure and hypotension.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 103.9°F (39.9°C), heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure of 94/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on 50% FiO2. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PCV mode, set at 23 cmH2O, PEEP at 10 cmH2O, and a rate of 20 breaths per minute.

The patient has a history of liver cirrhosis and ascites, as well as a recent large-volume paracentesis. He also has a hypoechoic lesion in the liver concerning for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The patient's renal function is impaired, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 4.0 mL/min/1.73m2.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including sepsis, hypotension, respiratory failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and liver cirrhosis. He is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and medications

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multi-organ failure and septic shock. The patient's condition has been unstable, with persistent fever, hypotension, and altered mental status. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Blood cultures were obtained to identify the causative organism of the infection. Antibiotic therapy with Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) was started. The patient is also receiving vasopressor support with Fentanyl and Midazolam for sedation. Dialysis catheter placement was performed to manage renal dysfunction. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Persistent septic shock leading to further organ dysfunction or failure.
2. Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Complications related to dialysis catheter placement, such as bleeding or infection.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis and inadequate renal perfusion.
5. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to severe pneumonia and sepsis.
6. Nosocomial infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or hospital-acquired pneumonia.
7. Hemodynamic instability and arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances and cardiac dysfunction.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding or stress ulcers due to prolonged critical illness and use of corticosteroids.
9. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism

Chief Complaint: respiratory distress
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI (cards thought it was NSTEMI [**2-17**] demand). Pt  was
   transferred to medicine for ascites and bradycardia, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   Albumin x1. Therapeutic paracentesis (1.8L) which improved ventilation
   and oxygenation (and reduced bladder pressures). Inotropes not
   required. CXR with L pleural effusion. ABG c/w acute repiratory
   acidosis. BiPap not tolerated, so intubated yesterday at 8PM. PCV for
   high PIPs.

He was admitted for upper extremity gangrene and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**], which was complicated by perioperative MI. The patient was transferred to medicine for ascites and bradycardia and is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and potential sources of infection including SBP, pneumonia, lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skin cellulitis around graft site, and UTI. Decreased venous return due to ascites may also contribute to hypotension.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic upon arrival to the unit in the setting of somnolence. ABG showed acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia, likely aggravated by a large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history.

Chief Complaint:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD
   s/p perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity
   gangrene, underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]
   complicated by perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for
   ascites and bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management
   of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

Other possible contributions include a productive cough developed during hospitalization. The patient is currently on 23/12 PCV. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD who was admitted for worsening peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. The patient had complications including perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He was transferred to the medicine service due to comorbidities and is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient has been experiencing fevers, tachycardia, and leukocytosis, indicating potential sepsis or infection. The source of infection could be spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), right subclavian/ left hemodialysis line, pneumonia, or urosepsis. The patient's heart failure is less likely as he responds well to fluid resuscitation.

The patient's respiratory failure is most likely due to a new left pleural effusion, which has resolved after therapeutic paracentesis. Other possible contributions include a productive cough developed during hospitalization. The patient is currently on pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV).

The patient's increasing INR suggests a possible coagulopathy or bleeding risk. There is also a concern for right fourth peripheral intravenous catheter-related osteomyelitis (PIPO), but this graft will not be used for arterial blood gas (ABG) sampling. The patient has a history

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD
   s/p perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity
   gangrene, underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]
   complicated by perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for
   ascites and bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management
   of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD. He underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery but experienced perioperative MI. He was transferred to medicine due to ascites and bradycardia and is now in the MICU for hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient has a history of worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 01/12/2111. He also had a perioperative MI and was transferred to medicine for comorbidities. He is currently being managed for hypotension and respiratory failure.

His hospital course has been complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op, a 4L paracentesis on 01/13/2111, and development of new ascites after being told he had cleared his Hep C. He has significant alcohol history but quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. He has had a tap on 01/13/2111 that was negative for SBP, and RUQ US on 01/20/2111 showed evidence of cirrhosis and a hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.

The patient is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery, plastic surgery, cardiology, nephrology, and hepatology. He was transferred to medicine on 01/21/2111. In the two days prior to admission to the MICU, he was noted

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to weane vent
   - vanc/zosyn
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
   - SBT
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with GNRs.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%

   - will attempt to resite CVL, place a-line

   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on

   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.

   - cont ASA, plavix, statin

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to wean vent
   - vanc. will change zosyn to meropenem given resp failure
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics- currently
   bladder pressures 15
   - SBT
   - attempt volume off for improved oxygenation via CVVH
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - antibiotics as above; consider linezolid if decompensates given
   history of VRE
   - sputum, blood cx pending
   - check bladder pressure q12
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose

   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin

Summary:
Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**], which was complicated by perioperative MI. He is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is experiencing respiratory failure, as indicated by hypoxia and hypercapnia. This could be aggravated by his large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history.
2. Sepsis/hypotension: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity infection. He has positive SBP on tap and other potential sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skin (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained after Foley placement).
3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] had a left brachial to radial bypass procedure, which may be affected by his PVD. There is also a concern for right 4th PIP osteomyelitis.
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] has cirrhosis and ascites, with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US concerning for HCC. Normal AFP levels were noted, and repeat u/s in 3 months is planned.
5. CAD s/ MI: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] has a history of CAD with perioperative MI.
6. ESRD: Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] requires regular HD on a qMWF schedule.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the provided progress note. Further evaluation and assessment by a healthcare professional are necessary for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic upon arrival to the unit. He has a history of smoking and may have underlying lung disease. The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia are likely aggravated by his large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease.

2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source. He has positive SBP on tap on [**2111-1-23**]. Other sources of infection include pneumonia, lines, skin (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained after Foley placement). Decreased venous return may also be contributing due to ascites.

The patient underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] and was admitted for worsening PVD. The patient developed hypotension and respiratory failure postoperatively and was transferred to the MICU.

   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Improved with 1.6L paracentesis.
   -  Extubated this morning.
   - cont vanc/meropenem for urosepsis
   - continue with volume off on CVVH goal -1 to -2L/day
   - daily bladder pressures

   [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.
   - maintain MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - cont vanoc/meropenem, needs 7 day course; consider linezolid if
   decompensates given history of VRE
   - f/u sputum, blood cx

   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular recs

   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and a history of perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. However, he developed complications such as perioperative MI and was transferred to the medicine department due to comorbidities. Now, he is being transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient has several medical issues that need to be addressed. 

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic upon arrival to the unit. This is likely due to factors such as a large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from his smoking history. However, he does not have a diagnosis of COPD. The patient's condition improved after a 1.6L paracentesis. He was extubated in the morning and should continue with vanc/meropenem for urosepsis. The goal is to maintain a MAP (mean arterial pressure) greater than 60 and SVO2 (mixed venous oxygen saturation) greater than 70%.

2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and tested positive for SBP (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis) on tap prior to transfer. He should continue

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. Postoperatively, he experienced a perioperative MI and PVD. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing hypoxia and hypercapnia, likely aggravated by factors such as a large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history. Improving respiratory mechanics may be necessary to manage this condition.

2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient has positive SBP on tap and urine culture showing resistant Klebsiella. Maintaining mean arterial pressures (MAPs) above 60 and superior vena cava oxygen saturation (SVO2) above 70% are important for managing sepsis-related hypotension. The patient needs a 7-day course of vancomycin and meropenem, and consideration should be given to adding linezolid if the patient decompensates due to vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE).

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery on 1/12. Postoperatively, he experienced a perioperative MI and was transferred to the medicine department for management of comorbidities. He is now in the MICU for hypotension and possible sepsis.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic upon arrival to the unit. He has a productive cough developing during hospitalization, indicating pneumonia (PNA). He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. There are plans to wean off the ventilator, change antibiotics, and consider a repeat therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics.

2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source of infection. He has positive SBP on tap, pneumonia, lines infection, skin infection, and UTI. He has decreased venous return due to ascites. The goal is to maintain MAPs > 60 and SVO2 > 70%. Antibiotics have been started, and consideration is given to linezolid due to the history of VRE. Blood and sputum cultures are pending.

3. PVD/left brachial to radial bypass/right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's vascular access will not use this graft for ABGs due to discussion with surgery. He also has R BKA and L AKA. Vascular recourses are planned.

4. HCV cirrhosis/liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on 1/13 associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. He has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US concerning for HCC. Normal AFP, and a plan for repeat US in 3 months per liver. Albumin is given for volume expansion, and consideration is given to paracentesis if bladder pressure increases.

5. CAD s/MI: The patient had perioperative ischemia during CABG surgery. Continuing ASA, Plavix, and statin therapy is recommended.

6. ESRD: The patient is on a qMWF HD schedule. CVVH is attempted today with fluid off as tolerated.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
- Respiratory failure due to pneumonia and difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation.
- Sepsis/hypotension due to multiple sources of infection, including SBP, pneumonia, lines infection, skin infection, and UTI.
- Liver failure due to HCV cirrhosis and liver mass, which may progress to hepatic encephalopathy or hepatorenal syndrome.
- Cardiac complications due to CAD and previous MI, including ischemia during CABG surgery.
- Renal failure due to ESRD and possible progression to acute kidney injury.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, infection parameters, liver function, cardiac function, and renal function to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD who presented to the ICU for worsening peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. He was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure, possibly due to sepsis. The patient has been extubated successfully and is doing well post-extubation. 

The patient's vital signs include a heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 123/55 to 89/40 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His temperature is within normal range at 36.6°C (97.9°F). 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, platelet count, and creatinine levels. His electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for slightly low potassium and high bicarbonate levels. Liver enzymes and other lab parameters are also within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals muscle wasting, clear breath sounds, symmetric chest expansion, and no abnormal findings in the cardiovascular, abdominal, extremities, or neurologic systems.

The assessment and plan include multiple medical conditions, such as HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, perioperative MI, and PVD. The patient's recent issues include hypotension and respiratory failure, which have improved after volume removal

The patient is a 75-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with chronic renal failure, acidosis, respiratory shock, and septic shock. The patient has been extubated and is doing well on a nasal cannula. He has been off pressors all day and his CVVH was stopped. The patient's blood pressure dropped at around 8 PM, so 25 gm albumin was given without much improvement.    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Improved with 1.6L paracentesis.
   -  Extubated this morning.
   - cont vanc/meropenem for urosepsis
   - continue with volume off on CVVH goal -1 to -2L/day
   - daily bladder pressures
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap on
   [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.
   - maintain MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - cont vanoc/meropenem, needs 7 day course; consider linezolid if
   decompensates given history of VRE
   - f/u sputum, blood cx
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular recs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin PRN for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver recs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH - attempt fluid off as tolerated
   - renal recs

Summary of Progress Note:

- The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD who was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery.
- He had a perioperative MI and was transferred to the ICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.
- The patient was extubated this morning and is currently on nasal cannula oxygen.
- He has been off pressors all day and was taken off CVVH.
- His blood pressure dropped at around 8 PM, but there were no mental status changes with low BPs.
- The patient has a history of smoking and has underlying lung disease.
- He showed improvement after a 1.6L paracentesis.
- He is currently on vancomycin and meropenem for urosepsis and needs a 7-day course.
- The patient's sepsis and hypotension are being managed by maintaining MAPs > 60 and SVO2 > 70%.
- He is also being monitored for sputum and blood cultures.
- The patient has a history of HCV and a liver mass concerning for HCC.
- He has cirrhosis and ascites with a previous tap on 1-13 associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.
- His liver function is being monitored with plans for repeat ultrasound in 3 months.
- The patient has a history of CAD and had a perioperative MI.
- He is currently on ASA, Plavix, and a statin.
- The patient has ESRD and is on a qMWF HD schedule.
- His renal function is being closely monitored.
- The patient is on a multi-lumen line, dialysis catheter, and prophylactic heparin for DVT and stress ulcers.
- His code status is full code, and his disposition is still pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of respiratory failure, hypercapnia, and hypoxia. Continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation and ABG analysis is necessary to prevent further respiratory complications.

2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and positive SBP. Close monitoring of blood pressure and appropriate antibiotic therapy is crucial to prevent septic shock.

3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's bypass graft may not be used for ABGs due to osteomyelitis. Regular vascular assessments are essential to monitor graft patency and prevent further complications.

4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and a liver mass concerning for HCC. Regular monitoring of liver function and follow-up ultrasounds are needed to assess the progression of liver disease.

5. CAD s/ MI: The patient has a history of CAD and perioperative MI. Close monitoring of cardiac enzymes and ongoing management of risk factors such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes are necessary to prevent further cardiac events.

6. ESRD: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is on dialysis. Close monitoring of renal function and adherence to the dialysis schedule are essential to prevent further complications related to renal dysfunction.

7. Potential infections: Given the patient's immunocompromised state, regular surveillance for infections, including monitoring of vital signs, temperature, and culture results, is important to prevent and manage any potential infections.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a medical history of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) cirrhosis, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), diabetes mellitus (DM), coronary artery disease (CAD), and peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent a left brachial to radial bypass surgery on [**2111-1-12**]. He was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) from the operating room due to hypotension and suspected sepsis.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, sepsis/hypotension, severe PVD, HCV cirrhosis/liver mass, CAD with demand ischemia peri-operatively, and cellulitis. He is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics (Vancomycin and Meropenem), norepinephrine, albumin, heparin sodium, and morphine sulfate.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
- Heart rate: 102 bpm (normal range: 93-120 bpm)
- Blood pressure: 91/72 mmHg (normal range: 76/48-138/85 mmHg)
- Respiratory rate: 19 breaths per minute (normal range: 3-29 breaths per minute)
- Oxygen saturation: 99% on nasal cannula

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 01/12/2111, which was complicated by perioperative MI. The patient is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and a positive sample for SBP on tap on 01/23/2111 prior to transfer. The plan includes maintaining mean arterial pressures (MAPs) above 60 and systemic vascular oxygen saturation (SVO2) above 70%. The patient is currently on meropenem, and consideration should be given to adding linezolid if the patient decompensates due to history of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE). Diagnostic paracentesis is scheduled today to evaluate for possible spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) with resistant organisms or VRE. Albumin will be administered at 25 gm once today, and efforts will be made to wean levophed off as tolerated while rechecking blood pressures.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic on arrival to the unit

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD. He was admitted for worsening peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and underwent a left brachial to radial bypass surgery. The patient then experienced a perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) and peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) due to hypotension and suspected sepsis.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, severe PVD, HCV cirrhosis/liver mass, CAD s/MI, and cellulitis. The patient is still on low-dose norepinephrine and is being attempted to wean off. He has a central venous pressure (CVP) line, arterial line, and a dialysis catheter. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 107 bpm, blood pressure of 115/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate levels. Other lab results are within normal limits or show no significant abnormalities.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include worsening respiratory failure due to underlying lung issues or infections, further deterioration of

- Glucose: within normal range at 119 mg/dL
- Troponin-T: elevated at 3.30 ng/mL

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Initially intubated for hypercapneic resp
   failure in setting of somnolence (missed cpap while inpatient and
   started on gabapentin) and sepsis.  Improved with 1.6L paracentesis and
   extubated on [**2111-1-27**].  Reintubated again on [**2111-1-29**] in setting of
   hypercapnea, concern for worsening sepsis vs oversedation after
   restarting ms contin.  Resp dynamics also aggravated by large abdomen,
   pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and
   underlying lung disease from smoking history.  Removed 1L + 2L
   paracentesis on [**1-29**].
   - wean sedation and trial of PS
   - cont meropenem/vanc; added gent ([**2111-1-29**]) for double coverage but
   will hold for now
   - bladder pressures q6h
   - avoid sedating meds when extubated
   - goals of care discussion with family
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap on
   [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  BP more stable now.
   - maintain MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - cont meropenem, needs 7 day course (last day [**2111-1-31**]); also on vanc
   and started gent ([**1-29**])
   - consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - f/u cx data
   - albumin 25 gm prn
   - wean off levophed to off as tolerated
   - correlate cuff pressures and femoral a-line
   # Anemia:  likely in setting of multiple blood draws and procedures on
   [**2111-1-29**].  Has ACI.
   - recheck hct
   - guaiac stools
   - transfuse for hct < 25 though does have CAD
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular recs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin PRN for volume expansion
   - lactulose
   - liver recs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH - attempt fluid off as tolerated
   - renal recs

Summary of Progress Note:
Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**], which was complicated by perioperative MI. The patient then experienced hypotension and urosepsis, leading to his transfer to the MICU.

The patient initially required intubation for hypercapneic respiratory failure, but was extubated on [**2111-1-27**]. However, he was reintubated on [**2111-1-29**] due to worsening sepsis and hypercapnea. The patient's respiratory dynamics are complicated by a large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history.

The patient has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap on [**2111-1-23**]. His blood pressure is more stable now, but he requires continued antibiotic coverage with meropenem. He also needs close monitoring of MAPs and SVO2 levels.

The patient is likely anemic due to multiple blood draws and procedures on [**2111-1-29**]. He has ACI and requires reevaluation of HCT levels.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD who was admitted for worsening PVD. He underwent a left brachial to radial bypass surgery on [**2111-1-12**] and was transferred to the MICU due to hypotension and suspected sepsis. The patient has multiple comorbidities including respiratory failure, severe peripheral vascular disease, liver mass, and a history of myocardial infarction. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been reintubated due to worsening acidemia and hypercarbia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's worsening respiratory condition, indicated by increased pCO2 levels and subsequent reintubation, suggests a high risk of further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The presence of hypotension and suspected sepsis raises concerns about potential organ dysfunction and septic shock.
3. Severe Peripheral Vascular Disease (PVD): The patient's history of PVD and recent bypass surgery puts him at risk for complications related to inadequate blood flow to the extremities, such as tissue necrosis or gangrene.
4. Liver Mass/HCC: The 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion raises concerns for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Close monitoring and further evaluation are necessary to determine the appropriate management plan.
5. History of CAD/MI:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and a history of perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative MI. The patient was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient has several medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: Initially intubated for hypercapneic respiratory failure in the setting of somnolence (missed CPAP while inpatient and started on gabapentin) and sepsis. Improved with 1.6L paracentesis and extubated on [**2111-1-27**]. Reintubated again on [**2111-1-29**] in the setting of hypercapnea, concern for worsening sepsis vs oversedation after restarting MS Contin. Resp dynamics also aggravated by large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history.

2. Sepsis/hypotension: Has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer. BP more stable now.

3. Anemia: Likely in the setting of multiple blood draws

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD on HD, DM, and CAD presenting with multiple medical complications. He initially came in for a brachial to radial bypass and subsequently experienced cardiac arrest during a large volume paracentesis. The patient was transferred to the floor and then back to the ICU due to SBP and EXBL klebsiella septic shock requiring pressors, as well as hypercarbic respiratory failure necessitating intubation. He was extubated on 1/27 but reintubated on 1/29 for hypercarbic respiratory failure. Currently, the patient requires CVVH due to vasopressor requirement.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has persistent ventilatory dependence likely due to increased abdominal pressures, resultant restrictive lung disease, and oversedation. Weaning off fentanyl and using propofol drip to increase sedation could help in weaning him off the ventilator.

2. Hypotension and Vasopressor Requirement: The patient has persistent hypotension and continues to require vasopressors. Possible etiologies include septic shock, abdominal compartment syndrome, and possible adrenal insufficiency. Checking CVP, CVO2, and lactate levels, awaiting urine culture sensitivities, and continuing meropenem and vancomycin are recommended. If no gram-positive organisms are found tomorrow

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old man with multiple medical conditions including hepatitis C cirrhosis, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), diabetes mellitus (DM), coronary artery disease (CAD) with a myocardial infarction (MI) and an ejection fraction (EF) of 20%, and restrictive ventilatory failure in the setting of abdominal compartment syndrome from ascites.

The patient was initially admitted for a left brachial-to-radial bypass procedure. He experienced cardiac arrest during a large volume paracentesis and was transferred to the floor before being readmitted to the ICU for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) Klebsiella septic shock requiring vasopressors and hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation. He was initially extubated on January 27th but had to be reintubated on January 29th due to hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient now requires continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) due to vasopressor requirement.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C (97.5%), heart rate of 94 bpm (90-107), blood pressure ranging from 101/54 mmHg to 128/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute (11-24), and oxygen saturation of 100

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a medical history of type I diabetes mellitus, chronic renal failure, and chronic viral hepatitis. He was admitted to the ICU due to acute respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation and various medications, including insulin for glycemic control. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 101/54 mmHg to 128/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His temperature is within normal range at 36.4°C. 

Laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cell count, creatinine, lactate, and troponin-T, along with low levels of hemoglobin, platelet count, potassium, and albumin. The arterial blood gas analysis indicates a pH of 7.40, pCO2 of 52, pO2 of 135, and HCO3 of 33. 

Fluid analysis of the peritoneal fluid reveals an elevated white blood cell count, numerous red blood cells, presence of polymorphonuclear cells, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and macrophages. 

Imaging pending includes a chest X-ray.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Initially intubated for hypercapneic resp
   failure in setting of somnolence (missed cpap while inpatient and
   started on gabapentin) and sepsis.  Improved with 1.6L paracentesis and
   extubated on [**2111-1-27**].  Reintubated again on [**2111-1-29**] in setting of
   hypercapnea, concern for worsening sepsis vs oversedation after
   restarting ms contin.  Resp dynamics also aggravated by large abdomen,
   pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and
   underlying lung disease from smoking history.  Removed 1L + 2L
   paracentesis on [**1-29**] and another 5L on [**1-31**].
   - Vt have improved post para, and MV also improved.  Currently [**5-20**].
   Planned extubation today.
   - cont meropenem/vanc.  Hold off on double coverage for now
   - bladder pressures q6h
   - avoid sedating meds when extubated; PRN sedation boluses
   - goals of care discussion with family- family meeting on Monday [**2-2**]
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap on
   [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  BP more stable now.  Repeat urine culture
   from [**1-29**] with GNRs again, awaing sensitivities.
   - maintain MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - cont meropenem, needs 7 day course (last day [**2111-1-31**])- will continue
   meropenem for now until the culture sensitivities available; also on
   vanc- will keep vanco on for one more day, if all cultures still no
   GPC, will stop vanco today
   - consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - f/u cx data- ask micro to get sensitivities on [**1-29**] urine culture in
   case meropenem resistant
   - albumin 25 gm prn; but first check CVP and MVO2 sat along with
   lactate
   - wean off levophed to off as tolerated
   - restarted on midodrine 5 mg TID
   - d/w hepatology re peritoneal drain
   # Anemia:  likely in setting of multiple blood draws and procedures on
   [**2111-1-29**].  Has ACI.
   - [**Hospital1 **] Hct
   - guaiac stools- positive
   - transfuse for hct < 25 though does have CAD possibly later today
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular recs
   - fenatyl and oxycodone for pain control, will address w/ goals of care
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin PRN for volume expansion if volume down (CVP/MvO2 as above)
   - lactulose/rifaximin
   - liver recs.  d/w hepatology regarding drain
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH - attempt fluid off as tolerated
   - renal recs

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and previous perioperative MI. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery on [**2111-1-12**], which was complicated by perioperative MI. The patient is currently in the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated multiple times due to hypercapneic respiratory failure, concern for worsening sepsis, oversedation, and underlying lung disease. There is a planned extubation today.
2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and positive SBP on tap. He is stable now, but repeat urine culture from [**1-29**] showed GNRs. Cultures are awaiting sensitivities.
3. Anemia: The patient likely has anemia due to multiple blood draws and procedures on [**2111-1-29**]. He has ACI and a Hct of [**Hospital1 **].
4. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's graft will not be used for ABGs, and he has a history of R BKA and L AKA.
5. HCV Cirrhosis/L

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and previous perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery on [**2111-1-12**], which was complicated by a perioperative MI. The patient then developed hypotension and urosepsis and required transfer to the MICU.

The patient initially required intubation for hypercapneic respiratory failure due to somnolence and sepsis. He showed improvement with paracentesis and was successfully extubated. However, he required reintubation due to hypercapnea and worsening sepsis. The patient underwent multiple paracentesis procedures and is now successfully extubated again.

The patient has urosepsis and a positive SBP on tap. His blood pressure is stable, but he needs close monitoring of MAPs and SVO2. He is currently on meropenem and vancomycin, which will be continued until culture sensitivities are available. If the cultures show resistance to meropenem, linezolid may be considered.

The patient also has anemia, likely due to multiple blood draws and procedures. He has a history of ACI and a positive guaiac stool, indicating gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient initially required intubation for hypercapneic respiratory failure and sepsis but has since been successfully extubated. He continues to require mechanical ventilation support with CPAP or possibly BIPAP overnight.

The patient has been receiving various medications and infusions, including midazolam, heparin, and fentanyl.

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include:

2. Pneumonia: The chest X-ray shows persistent enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and retrocardiac opacification, which could indicate atelectasis or pneumonia. Given the clinical setting, supervening pneumonia must be seriously considered.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD on HD, DM, CAD s/p MI with EF 20%, admitted initially for L brachial to radial bypass. He experienced cardiac arrest during a large volume paracentesis and was transferred to the ICU for SBP and ESBL klebsiella infection causing septic shock. He also has hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient is currently on CPAP and pressors, but was extubated and reintubated due to worsening respiratory failure. He has a history of R AKA and L BKA, multiple necrotic fingers on L hand, and ulcerated R PIP. His current vital signs are stable, but he is still dependent on the ventilator. He has several medical conditions including severe ischemic cardiomyopathy, ESLD, ESRD, multiorgan failure, abdominal compartment syndrome, recurrent hypercarbic respiratory failure, and an ESBL UTI. He is receiving meropenem for the ESBL klebsiella UTI and will continue it pending urine culture results. His respiratory failure is likely due to extrinsic obstruction and volume overload, but has improved and he was recently extubated. The plan is to trial BiPAP and work towards long-term noninvasive ventilation. Other issues include chronic viral hepatitis with cirrhosis, requiring monitoring for complications such as ascites and hepatorenal syndrome. He requires chronic renal replacement therapy and management of chronic anemia. Pain control is also a concern. The patient's code status is full code, and he will remain in the MICU for now.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has an ESBL UTI and SBP. There is a risk of developing further infections due to his immunocompromised state and prolonged ICU stay.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has recurrent hypercarbic respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening if not managed properly. There is a risk of reintubation if he does not tolerate BiPAP or if his respiratory status worsens.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has severe ischemic cardiomyopathy and is at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
4. Hepatic Decompensation: The patient has ESLD with complications such as ascites. There is a risk of hepatic decompensation and associated complications like hepatorenal syndrome.
5. Renal Failure: The patient has ESRD and requires chronic renal replacement therapy. There is a risk of worsening renal function and further complications.
6. Bleeding: The patient has a history of multiple blood draws, which can contribute to anemia. Additionally, he has a history of vascular procedures, increasing the risk of bleeding.
7. Thromboembolic Events: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease and chronic immobilization in the ICU, increasing the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

The patient is a 55-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and a history of perioperative MI and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. The patient then developed hypotension and urosepsis, leading to transfer to the MICU. The patient's main issues include respiratory failure, sepsis/hypotension, anemia, PVD/left brachial to radial bypass/right 4th PIP osteomyelitis, HCV cirrhosis/liver mass, and CAD s/MI.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has had multiple episodes of respiratory failure requiring intubation. There is concern for worsening sepsis, oversedation, large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease due to smoking history. The patient has been successfully extubated but will need close monitoring of his respiratory status.

2. Sepsis/Hypotension: The patient has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap. Despite being stable now, there is a need to maintain MAPs > 60 and SVO2 > 70%. The patient is currently on meropenem and vancomycin, which will be continued until culture sensitivities are available. Consideration should also be given to line

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of Hep C cirrhosis, recurrent ascites, ESRD on HD, CAD, and ischemic CM, who was admitted to the ICU with SBP and ESBL Klebsiella UTI. The patient was treated for septic shock, which is now resolved. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation due to hypercarbic respiratory failure.

24-hour events include a repeat family meeting to discuss goals of care, with the patient still being full code. The patient will receive HD today and received 1 unit of PRBC yesterday for Hct 24.6.

The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. The last dose of antibiotics was given on [**2111-1-31**] at 08:07 PM and [**2111-2-3**] at 08:37 AM.

The patient is currently on several medications, including heparin sodium (prophylaxis), fentanyl, simvastatin, nephrocaps, lidocaine patch, Plavix 75 daily, RISS, ASA 81 daily, lactulose TID, meropenem 500mg IV q8hr, Pepcid, rifaximin 400 TID, and midodrin 5mg TID.

Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.

- Temperature (Tmax): 37°C (98.6°F)
- Temperature (Tcurrent): 37°C (98.6°F)
- Heart rate (HR): 94 bpm (86-105 bpm)
- Blood pressure (BP): 117/65 mmHg (81-144/43-103 mmHg)
- Respiratory rate (RR): 20 breaths per minute (10-30 breaths per minute)

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 55-year-old man with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, recurrent ascites, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis (ESRD), coronary artery disease (CAD) with ischemic cardiomyopathy, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD) status post bilateral below-knee amputation. He was admitted to the ICU with septic shock and hypercarbic respiratory failure, which have since resolved.

The patient's current condition includes severe ischemic cardiomyopathy, ESLD, ESRD, multiorgan failure, abdominal compartment syndrome, recurrent hypercarbic respiratory failure (due to ACS from ascites), and an ESBL UTI. 

The patient's treatment plan includes finishing a 7-day course of meropenem, awaiting sensitivities from the Klebsiella in urine culture, continuing midodrine 5mg TID for blood pressure support, and considering a repeat therapeutic paracentesis due to rising bladder pressures. 

Other medical issues include chronic renal failure, chronic viral hepatitis/cirrhosis with associated complications such as ascites and extrinsic respiratory distress. The patient is currently tolerating hemodialysis and has a low threshold for paracentesis. 

In terms of ICU care, the patient is on regular diet, RISS for glycemic control, and various lines including a dialysis catheter, PICC line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line. Prophylaxis measures include D

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, recurrent ascites, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, and coronary artery disease. He was admitted to the ICU with septic shock due to an ESBL Klebsiella urinary tract infection, which has now resolved. The patient's current issues include severe ischemic cardiomyopathy, ESLD, ESRD, multiorgan failure, abdominal compartment syndrome, recurrent hypercarbic respiratory failure (due to ACS from ascites), and ESBL UTI.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of recurrent hypercarbic respiratory failure, which can be caused by abdominal compartment syndrome from ascites. This can lead to worsening hypercarbia and respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: Although the patient's septic shock has resolved, there is still a risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of an ESBL Klebsiella urinary tract infection. Monitoring for signs of infection and prompt treatment are crucial.
3. End-Stage Liver Disease (ESLD): The patient's ESLD puts him at risk for complications such as hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and portal hypertension.
4. End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD): The patient is on hemodialysis, and complications related to ESRD include fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and uremic symptoms.
